results.headline: When Dad’s Temper Was the Problem

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Mighty Fine

results.summary_short: “Mighty Fine,” about a family that moves from Brooklyn to New Orleans in 1974, features Chazz Palminteri as a father with anger-management issues.

results.headline: Back in the Day, When Agents and Aliens Were Sweet

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Men in Black 3

results.summary_short: “Men in Black 3” returns to the summer of 1969, in a swirl of nostalgia as naïve as “Forrest Gump” and as knowing as “Mad Men,” but not as sour as either.

results.headline: The Sweat, Tears and Passion Behind the Pixels

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Indie Game: The Movie

results.summary_short: “Indie Game: The Movie” is a tenderly wrought portrait of four independent video game designers.

results.headline: Faithful Companion at Work

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Quill

results.summary_short: “Quill: The Life of a Guide Dog” tells the story of the raising and training of a Labrador retriever.

results.headline: A Grifter Called On for One Last Con

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Samaritan

results.summary_short: In “The Samaritan,” Samuel L. Jackson stars as a former con man asked to assist in another swindle.

results.headline: When Mahler Met Freud

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Mahler on the Couch

results.summary_short: “Mahler on the Couch” dramatizes Gustav Mahler’s tempestuous marriage and his consultation with Sigmund Freud.

results.headline: Tormented Newlywed in a House Where Things Moan in the Night

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Lovely Molly

results.summary_short: In “Lovely Molly,” the director Eduardo Sanchez paints an intimate portrait of a tormented young newlywed and recovering addict in a haunted house.

results.headline: The Life and Death of an Israeli Hero
results.display_title: Follow Me: The Yoni Netanyahu Story

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Follow Me: The Yoni Netanyahu Story

results.summary_short: “Follow Me: The Yoni Netanyahu Story” remembers the commando who died at Entebbe.

results.headline: Gloomy Clinic Where the Staff Behaves as Oddly as the Inmates

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Beyond The Black Rainbow

results.summary_short: “Beyond the Black Rainbow” is set in a gloomy, underpopulated clinic outfitted with mysterious doors, where the staff members behave as oddly as the inmates.

results.headline: Mirroring Life’s Cruelty: Tale of a Photographer Tracking Child Victims

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Polisse

results.summary_short: “Polisse,” from Maïwenn, illuminates French society with a toughness and fidelity that few other recent movies have dared.

results.headline: Delivering Babies by the Book (Abridged )
results.display_title: What To Expect When You're Expecting

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of What To Expect When You're Expecting

results.summary_short: “What to Expect When You’re Expecting,” directed by Kirk Jones, takes the edge off Heidi Murkoff’s best seller, probably for the dads, mostly.

results.headline: Are We There Yet? On the Road, Sibling Rivalry That Reveals No Limits

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Color Wheel

results.summary_short: “The Color Wheel,” a black-and-white film approaching the mumblecore school, is written by its two stars.

results.headline: Troubles Without End in a Dead-End Town

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Virginia

results.summary_short: Dustin Lance Black’s film “Virginia” follows the chaotic life of the title character (played by Jennifer Connelly), who is schizophrenic.

results.headline: The Grooming of Men

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Mansome

results.summary_short: In “Mansome,” the documentarian Morgan Spurlock focuses on the many facets of men’s grooming.

results.headline: Who Knew Visiting the Doctor Back Then Could Be So Thrilling?

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hysteria

results.summary_short: In “Hysteria,” directed by Tanya Wexler, Hugh Dancy is a medical man in Victorian London with busy hands and satisfied female patients.

results.headline: Dying, Pronouncing and Releasing His Life Force

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of American Animal

results.summary_short: “American Animal,” written, produced, directed and starring Matt D’Elia, is about a terminally ill man given to delivering monologues to his patient roommate.

results.headline: Aliens, Your Weapons Are Utterly Useless Against Our Rogues

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Battleship

results.summary_short: “Battleship,” a movie loosely based on the Hasbro game, is a cacophonous special-effects extravaganza.

results.headline: Dark, Darwinian Struggles in the Jungle That Is Moscow

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Elena

results.summary_short: “Elena,” by Andrei Zvyagintsev, follows a married couple and their class resentments.

results.headline: The Tyrant as Tourist

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Dictator

results.summary_short: Sacha Baron Cohen’s newest creation, Admiral General Aladeen, is the star of the new comedy “The Dictator.”

results.headline: Five Centuries in Love: That’s a Lot of Past Lives

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Dangerous ISHHQ

results.summary_short: “Dangerous Ishhq,” starring Karisma Kapoor and Rajniesh Duggall, follows two lovers through their past lives.
